I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The People’s Republic of China (PRC) has experienced rapid urbanization over the last two 
decades of economic reforms, largely fueled by the transformation of suburban areas from farming 
to non-farming activity, and by the migration of surplus rural labor to urban areas.  Urbanization as 
a policy issue took on new importance after the Third Plenum of the 15th Party Congress in 1998, 
when it was elevated to a national strategy.  The Government highlighted urbanization as a key 
policy area in its 10th Five-Year Plan (2001–2005) and will continue to emphasize sustainable 
urbanization in the 11th Five-Year Plan (2006–2010). During the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
2005  country  programming  review  mission,  the  Government  requested  ADB  for  technical 
assistance (TA) to review its urbanization policies with a focus on strengthening capacities of 
metropolitan regions1 to sustain rapid urbanization. Fact-finding for the TA was undertaken in 
October  2005  and  an  understanding  was  reached  with  the  Government  on  the  impact  and 
outcome, scope, costs and financing, implementation arrangements, and terms of reference for the 
TA.2 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
  
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The Government sees urbanization as a way of reducing rural–urban inequalities and of 
sustaining  the  country’s  transition  to  a  market  economy.    Urbanization  can  make  a  major 
contribution  to  reducing  inequalities  because  productivity  and  wage  rates  in  urban  economic 
sectors  are  many  times  higher  than  those  in  the  agriculture  sector.  International  experience 
indicates that the more urbanized a country, the more likely it is to experience higher rates of 
productivity  and  resulting  prosperity.    Historical  patterns  of  development  suggest  that  an 
urbanization rate of 40–50% is often associated with rapid urban growth that begins to moderate 
when a country becomes about 70% urbanized. The United Nations projects that the PRC will 
reach 40% urbanization in 2005, 50% between 2010 and 2015, and 60% by 2030.              
 
3.  Many  cities  are  undergoing  rapid  growth  that  is  expanding  urban  areas  well  beyond 
traditional municipal boundaries.  The growth of metropolitan regions in the PRC over at least the 
past 15 years has largely been through accretion, with suburban households and firms avoiding 
administrative constraints to residency, employment, enterprise formation, and land tenure in urban 
districts.  Given rapidly increasing population densities in suburban areas, and the relative ease of 
industrial  enterprise  formation,  farming  areas  on  the  outskirts  of  urban  districts  have  been 
transformed into semiformal suburban precincts fairly easily.  The urbanization process is now 
being accelerated through migration, predominantly from rural areas but also from other cities.  
The result of these forces has been the explosion not only of coastal cities but also of some inland 
cities such as Chengdu.     
 
4.  There are today 53 metropolitan regions in the PRC anchored on cities with over 1 million 
non-farming residents and comprising selected adjacent counties and county-level cities.  They 
contain almost 370 million people, or 29% of the country’s population, but produce 53% of the 
PRC’s GDP and 62.3% of all non-farming GDP from manufacturing, construction, and services.  
Most of the PRC’s metropolitan regions still have low levels of urbanization, and hence unrealized 
agglomeration economies that generally come with highly urbanized regions.  Only 15 of 53 
metropolitan regions have urbanization levels over 70%.  Except for Urumqi, all the metropolitan 
regions in the central and western PRC have urbanization levels under 70%, with the majority in 
                                                 
1  Metropolitan regions are functional urban areas anchored on a statutory city with more than 1 million non-farming 
residents, and extending to cover labor and other input markets within an approximately 50-kilometer (km) radius of 
the core city, or a 1-hour drive time from the city center.  In the PRC such regions usually cross municipal boundaries.

the 40–60% range.  While just over half of the PRC’s metropolitan regions are in coastal provinces 
(28 of 53), half of these have urbanization levels under 70%.  There is therefore considerable 
scope for additional urbanization in both coastal and interior metropolitan regions. 
 
5.  Despite  their  low  levels  of  urbanization,  negative  externalities  of  urban  and  suburban 
growth are already becoming apparent and need to be addressed through more effective policy 
measures.  Air and water pollution continue to be serious problems in the PRC’s cities, and are 
now spreading to previously rural parts of suburban areas.  Carbon monoxide and nitrogen oxide 
from motor vehicle emissions are growing contributors to air pollution.  Water shortages and 
pollution continue to be major problems for many cities.  Of the PRC’s 658 cities, the Ministry of 
Water Resources (MWR) reports that 420 had water shortages at the end of 2003.  In 2001, 53% 
of monitored sections of the seven key river systems in the PRC had water quality of Class V or 
below.3 Land consumption is also becoming a serious issue.  Many of the PRC’s metropolitan 
regions  are  beginning  to  expand  rapidly  through  undirected  suburbanization.  The  result  is 
consumption of agricultural land and growing urban sprawl that is causing inefficient land use, land 
markets, goods transport, public transport, and public services.  In addition to worsening traffic 
congestion, many urban regions in the PRC have weak transport links between the core city and 
suburban towns, and between these towns.  This limits the participation of suburban workers in 
metropolitan labor markets and constrains the development of efficient supply relationships for 
suburban enterprises.  Aside from equity concerns, limited physical access drives up prices of 
inner-city labor and land and reduces competitiveness.  
 
6.  The PRC and ADB have collaborated in several projects focused on meeting the growing 
demand for urban infrastructure and improving the environmental quality of urban life in cities such 
as Anhui, Changchun, Fuzhou, Harbin, Shanghai, Tianjin, Wenzhou, Wuhan, and Zhangjiakou. 
These projects have typically included sewage treatment plants, water supply, and cleaning up 
rivers and lakes in the cities. Policy support and capacity building have also been provided through 
advisory TA. However, there is now an urgent need for ADB to adopt a more systematic and 
comprehensive approach to its support for urban development in the PRC. Urban development 
cuts across a number of sectors, including environment, water supply and sanitation, transport and 
energy and interventions often include several subprojects or components. Further, there is a need 
for ADB to broaden its involvement to cover projects that promote integrated urban development 
covering water supply and conservation, sewage treatment, solid waste management, clean air 
program and, vehicular emission reduction. 
 
7.  This  TA  is  a  response  to  the  Government’s  interest  in  promoting  urbanization  in 
metropolitan regions to strengthen agglomeration economies that can generate a wide range of 
employment opportunities for rural migrants.  However, the Government is also intent on making  
this urbanization environmentally sustainable. The TA will support the Government’s efforts to 
identify  and  promote  policies  that  ensure  the  economically  and  environmentally  sustainable 
urbanization of the PRC’s metropolitan regions. The TA will also provide recommendations on how 
ADB can help the Government to pursue a more systematic approach to urban development. The 
TA  will  complement  a  recently  completed  town-based  urbanization  strategy  TA  which 
recommended focusing development of towns in metropolitan regions and along transport and 
economic corridors.4

8.  ADB’s country strategy and program (CSP), 2004–2006,5 and CSP update (2006–2008)6 
for the PRC support the country’s development strategy and are designed to promote pro-poor 
economic growth by enabling the poor to have greater access to the opportunities and benefits of 
economic prosperity. ADB’s operational program aims to (i) reduce inequalities, (ii) make markets 
work better, (iii) improve the environment, and (iv) promote regional cooperation. A workable 
urbanization strategy, particularly for rapidly-growing metropolitan regions, can have a significant 
impact on pro-poor economic growth in the PRC. This TA is in line with the goals of the CSP and 
supports the Government’s economic development and poverty reduction objectives.   
 
9.  The  urban  sector  in  the  PRC  has  also  received  considerable  assistance  from  other 
multilateral and bilateral development partners.  The World Bank is currently carrying out a study 
on metropolitan area development in the PRC that is expected to focus on specific infrastructure 
and governance themes over the next 3 years. The World Bank, Japan Bank for International 
Cooperation (JBIC), Department for International Development of the United Kingdom, and others 
have supported water supply and wastewater treatment projects in many large cities, as well as 
more  comprehensive  urban  environmental  projects.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  in  close 
collaboration with the World Bank and other partners to ensure that TA outputs are effectively 
coordinated.    
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact of the TA7 will be seen in more effective urbanization processes and patterns, 
with fewer negative and more positive externalities. It will help to increase productivity and living 
standards. The first outcomes of the TA will be a coherent urbanization strategy adopted by the 
Government during the 11th Five-Year Plan, the selection of regions and cities to spearhead the 
PRC’s urbanization strategy, and the identification of priority investment and policy areas that will 
need special attention by the Government. The second group of outcomes will be an improved, 
focused, effective, and efficient ADB urban sector operational strategy in the PRC and a new 
PRC–ADB urban strategy to guide lending and nonlending operations over the next 5 years.    
          
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will have five parts. Part A, formulation of urbanization scenarios, will consist of 
three sets of urbanization scenarios to 2020 for the PRC as a whole, for the Sichuan Plain region, 
for the middle Yangtze region, and for the metropolitan regions of Chengdu (Sichuan province) and 
Wuhan (Hubei province).8 These scenarios will reflect varying assumptions on the rate, timing, and 
location of urbanization.  
  
12.  Part B, implications of urbanization scenarios, will assess the scenarios for Chengdu and 
Wuhan in the following areas.

(i)  Employment  generation  required  to  sustain  the  scenarios,  supported  by  an 
assessment of the production capacities, competitiveness, and market conditions 
needed to realize sustainable employment. 
(ii)  Social services capacities, especially for education, training, and health services, 
including in suburban areas, and social security, including for rural migrants. 
(iii)  Environmental carrying capacities, with a focus on land requirements, implications 
for food production, supply of potable water, and energy requirements. 
(iv)  Infrastructure  capacities,  including  water  treatment,  domestic  and  industrial 
wastewater treatment, and domestic solid waste. 
(v)  Transport capacities, including the roads and regional public rail systems needed to 
meet the demands of each scenario. 
(vi)  Governance  capacities,  especially  in  the  planning  and  monitoring  of  urban 
development, and delivery of infrastructure, transport, and social services. 
(vii)  Financing capacities, to support the capital and recurrent investments implied by 
each scenario. 
13.  Part C, policy options, will review successful and unsuccessful policy experiences in four 
metropolitan regions in other countries that share key characteristics of metropolitan regions in the 
PRC. A study tour by key National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) officials to these 
case study cities will focus on specific policies addressing the implications identified in Part B.  
Successful policies applied in the PRC will also be identified and documented.  A policy matrix will 
be prepared that identifies the relevance, effectiveness, efficacy, institutional requirements, and 
dependencies of each policy.  Policy options will be reviewed at a workshop attended by central 
government agencies, representatives of the provincial governments of Sichuan and Hubei, and 
municipal governments of Wuhan and Chengdu. Based on the workshop discussions, NDRC will 
identify the policy options most relevant to the PRC.   
  
14.  Part D, policy framework, will consist of consultants recommending the most appropriate 
instruments for the selected policies to be implemented, and the phasing and implementation 
responsibilities among levels of government.  Part E, PRC–ADB urban strategy, will consist of 
consultants working with ADB and the Government to develop a five-year strategy and action plan 
to guide ADB’s lending and nonlending operations in the PRC.  This strategy will address the 
demands of metropolitan regions, but could include smaller cities and towns.  
 
15.  Three  workshops  will  be  held.  The  first,  in  Beijing,  will  focus  on  developing  realistic 
assumptions to guide the preparation of the urbanization scenarios for the country as a whole, for 
the Sichuan plain and the middle Yangtze region. This workshop will be attended by central 
government representatives, senior academics and policy advisors.  The second workshop will be 
held at the conclusion of part C, policy options. It will be held in either Chengdu or Wuhan and, in 
addition to central government representatives, it will include officials from the Sichuan and Hubei 
provincial  governments,  and  from  the  municipal  governments  of  Chengdu  and  Wuhan.    The 
purpose of this workshop will be to review policy options for supporting sustainable urbanization of 
metropolitan regions in the PRC and to develop a consensus on to the most practicable policies.  
The  final  workshop  will  be  held  in  Beijing  and,  aside  from  central,  provincial  and  municipal 
governments, will include representatives from the World Bank, the European Union, JBIC, and 
bilateral agencies with urban operations in the PRC.  The purpose of this workshop will be to 
present and review the TA findings with a focus on the recommended policy framework and the 
PRC–ADB urban strategy.

5
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $625,000 equivalent, of which $302,000 is the 
foreign exchange cost and $323,000 equivalent is the local currency cost.  The Government has 
requested ADB to finance $500,000 equivalent, covering the entire foreign exchange cost and 
$198,000 equivalent of the local currency cost.  The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
TA funding program. The Government of the PRC has agreed to provide the balance of the local 
currency cost, equivalent to $125,000 for counterpart staff, office space, furniture, administrative 
support, logistics, and interpretation services. Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are 
in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  NDRC’s Department of Development Planning (DDP) will be the Executing Agency for the 
TA.    DDP  will  form  a  steering  committee  and  provide  policy  guidance,  facilitate  interagency 
coordination, and address any institutional problems.  The steering committee will be composed of 
representatives of NDRC, Ministry of Finance (MOF), Ministry of Construction (MOC), MWR, State 
Environmental  Protection  Agency  (SEPA),  Ministry  of  Natural  Resources  and  Land  (MNRL), 
Ministry of Civil Affairs (MCA), and the two case study provinces. It will meet at least three times 
during the course of the TA: at inception, to review the interim report, and to review the draft final 
report.   
 
18.  DDP will appoint a senior officer as project manager, assisted by other qualified counterpart 
staff. NDRC will assure the cooperation of the case study provinces in working with the consultants 
and facilitating their work. It will also assure the participation of other ministries, including MOC, 
MWR, SEPA, and MNLR during implementation of the TA. Office space and facilities will be 
provided in Beijing by NDRC and in the two provinces by the provincial development and reform 
commissions. 
 
19.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 8 months beginning in May 2006 (shortly after 
the end of the National People’s Congress) and the expected completion date is December 2006. 
The TA will help the Government to formulate a detailed national urbanization strategy. The total 
input of the consultants is estimated at 30 person-months, consisting of 10 person-months of 
international  staff  and  20  person-months  of  domestic.    The  international  consulting  team  will 
provide a team leader with broad experience in all aspects of the urban sector and specialists in 
urban  development  policy,  urban  economics,  urban  environmental  management,  and  urban 
transport. The domestic team will include specialists with expertise in urban or regional geography, 
regional  economics,  water  resources  management,  water  and  wastewater  engineering,  urban 
transport planning, energy management, municipal finance, and financial analysis. The consultants 
will be engaged through a firm in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and 
other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for selecting and engaging domestic consultants. The 
quality-cost based selection method, using a simplified technical proposal, will be adopted. The 
outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3.   
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
20.  The  President,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved  the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of the People’s Republic of China for the Study on Sustainable Urbanization in 
Metropolitan Regions, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will consist of five closely related parts.  While the purpose 
of the TA is to inform national policies on sustainable urbanization, much of the work will focus 
on two representative metropolitan regions: the Chengdu metropolitan region, which includes 
the prefecture-level cities of Deyang and Mianyang to the north; and the Wuhan metropolitan 
region. The consultant team will coordinate and cooperate closely during implementation with 
another TA to be administered by ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department (PSOD):  PRC: 
Application of Public–Private Partnerships in Urban Railway-Based Transportation.   
 
A.  Part A: Formulation of Urbanization Scenarios 
2.  This component will consist of three sets of urbanization scenarios to 2020 for the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC) as a whole, for the Sichuan plain region,1 for the middle 
Yangtze region, and for the metropolitan regions of Chengdu2 (Sichuan province) and Wuhan 
(Hubei province).  These scenarios will reflect varying assumptions on the rate, timing, and 
location of urbanization.  Consultants will conduct the following activities. 
 
(i)   Obtain  from  leading  national  policy  institutes  the  most  recent  population 
projections for the PRC to the year 2020 and review the underlying demographic 
assumptions of these projections. 
(ii)  Review  with  the  State  Statistical  Bureau,  National  Development  and  Reform 
Commission (NDRC), Ministry of Construction (MOC), and leading national policy 
institutes their historical estimates of urbanization levels from 1970 to the present, 
and their estimates of urbanization rates to 2020 (accounting for differing official 
definitions of “urban” during the last 35 years).  
(iii)   Review  United  Nations,  World  Bank,  United  Nations  Centre  for  Human 
Settlements,  and  Economic  and  Social  Commission  for  Asia  and  the  Pacific 
projections of urbanization in East Asia and the PRC to 2020, and establish their 
convergence or otherwise with PRC Government projections. 
(iv)  Define key assumptions on economic growth and demographic changes in the 
PRC to 2020 to define the basis for urbanization scenarios.  
(v)  On the basis of these assumptions, prepare three urbanization scenarios at the 
national level including projections of urban populations to 2020.  
(vi)  Present these scenarios to government representatives at the first TA workshop in 
Beijing; participants will include personnel from NDRC, MOC, Ministry of Civil 
Affairs (MCA), Ministry of Labour and Social Security (MLSS), and Ministry of 
Natural Resources and Land (MNRL). 
(vii)  Adjust these national scenarios based on inputs from the workshop. 
(viii)  Based on the final national scenarios, prepare three linked urbanization scenarios 
for the middle Yangtze region and the Sichuan plain to 2020.  
(ix)  Through discussions with provincial and municipal governments in both Hubei and 
Sichuan,  prepare  three  urbanization  scenarios  to  2020  for  the  Chengdu  and 
                                                 
1  Including the province-level municipality of Chongqing. 
2  Including Deyang and Mianyang prefecture-level cities.

Appendix  3   11 
Wuhan  metropolitan regions to 2020, linked to the urbanization scenarios for their 
respective larger regions. 
(x)  Review  these  metropolitan  region  urbanization  scenarios  with  provincial  and 
municipal governments, and finalize them.  
B.  Part B: Implications of Urbanization Scenarios 
3.  The second component will consist of an assessment of the implications of urbanization 
scenarios for Chengdu and Wuhan on the following. 
 
(i)  Employment  generation  required  to  sustain  the  scenarios,  supported  by  an 
assessment of the production capacities, competitiveness, and market conditions 
needed to generate sustainable employment in the two metropolitan regions, 
including in suburban towns and satellite cities. 
(ii)  Social services capacities, especially for education, health services, and training 
of unskilled and semi-skilled rural migrant workers, including in suburban areas, 
and the provision of social security to rural migrants. 
(iii)  Land requirements, based on differing population densities and broad land uses 
emerging from the economic assumptions underlying the urbanization scenario. 
(iv)  Water  requirements  for  agricultural,  domestic,  industrial,  and  municipal 
consumption under each scenario. 
(v)  Energy requirements for transport, heating and cooling, and industry for each 
scenario. 
(vi)  Infrastructure requirements, including for water treatment, domestic and industrial 
wastewater  treatment,  and  domestic  solid  waste  to  meet  current  national 
standards. 
(vii)  Transport  requirements,  including expressway  and  feeder  roads  in  suburban 
areas, and regional public transport systems needed to reasonably meet the 
demands of each scenario. 
(viii)  Governance capacities, especially in the coordination of planning and monitoring 
of urban development, and in the efficient delivery of regional infrastructure, 
transport, and social services. 
(ix)  Financing capacities, to support the capital and recurrent investments implied 
under each scenario. 
 
C.  Part C: Policy Options 
4.  Part C will review of successful and unsuccessful policy experiences in other countries 
that  may  be  relevant  to  urbanization  scenarios  in  Chengdu  and  Wuhan,  and  to  other 
metropolitan regions in the PRC. This component will include case studies of 4–5 metropolitan 
regions that share key characteristics of metropolitan region growth with the two PRC case 
study regions and with other cities in the PRC. NDRC has already researched experiences in 
Japan and the United States extensively, and wishes to expand this research to include Asian 
and Latin American experience. Consultants will be encouraged to recommend and explain 
other options. A high-level study tour will be led by senior NDRC officials, who are directly 
responsible for formulation and implementation of urbanization strategies in the PRC,  to visit 
the case study cities to review specific policies and policy instruments. The consultant will

12  Appendix 3 
design the study tour, including the identification of themes and policies with NDRC, and the 
arrangement of meetings in all cities.  The study tour plan will be submitted for prior approval to 
the ADB project officer. 
 
5.  Successful  policies  applied  in  other  metropolitan  regions  in  the  PRC  will  also  be 
identified and documented.  A policy matrix will be prepared that identifies the relevance, 
effectiveness,  efficacy,  institutional  capacity  requirements,  and  policy  and  regulatory 
dependencies of each policy.   
 
6.  Policy options will be reviewed in a workshop attended by central government agencies, 
representatives of provincial governments of Hubei and Sichuan, and municipal governments of 
Chengdu, Deyang, Mianyang, and Wuhan.  Based on discussions at this workshop, NDRC will 
select the policy options it believes are most relevant to the PRC.  The consultant will organize 
this workshop and record discussions. 
 
D.  Part D: Policy Framework 
7.  The fourth component will consist of consultants recommending the most appropriate 
instruments through which the selected policies can be implemented, and the phasing and 
implementation responsibilities among levels of government.  Generally, three broad types of 
instruments will be assessed: provision of information and/or education; provision of economic 
incentives; and regulatory instruments.  For each policy in the framework, the consultant will 
define specific instruments that are likely to be most effective in implementing the policy.  These 
instruments will need to be specifically targeted at the level of government best equipped to 
implement the policy.   
 
8.  Phasing of policy recommendations will need to be carefully considered and described.  
Phasing should be tied to key points in the Five-Year Plan preparation process.     
 
E.  Part E: PRC–ADB Urban Strategy 
9.  The final component will consist of consultants working with ADB and Government 
representatives to develop a 5-year strategy and action plan to guide lending and non-lending 
operations in metropolitan regions and smaller cities and towns in the PRC.  
 
10.  For this component, the consultants will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Review ADB’s May 1999 urban sector profile and identify areas where it is 
outdated and where new information or new policy directions require it to be 
modified or added to.  
(ii)  Using the analyses completed under this TA and other sources, review and 
revise the discussion of urbanization trends contained in the 1999 report. 
(iii)  Revise  where  necessary  the  discussion  on  institutional,  legal  and  regulatory 
frameworks, incorporating the most recent changes and any planned changes. 
(iv)  Through extensive discussions with officials at NDRC, MOF, and other ministries, 
Identify and prioritize key issues that ADB’s program should address. 
(v)  Review  recent  changes  to  financing  modalities  and  operational  policies  and 
procedures at ADB and review with ADB project officers the possible implications 
of these changes on urban operations in the PRC.

Appendix  3   13 
(vi)  Review ADB’s most recent country strategy and program update, and ensure 
that  the  proposed  urban  strategy  reflects  the  policies  and  directions  in  that 
document.  
(vii)  Assess the situation with regard to external assistance, including that offered by  
ADB, other multilateral organizations, and bilateral aid.  Identify opportunities for 
better coordination of external assistance. 
(viii)  Develop proposals for the Bank’s strategy over the next five years, identify areas 
of intervention and policy dialogue, and review these in close consultation with 
East and Central Asia Regional Department/Social Sectors Division and ADB’s 
People’s Republic of China Resident Mission staff, and with the PRC officials in 
MOF and NDRC. 
(ix)  Recommend a new PRC–ADB urban strategy to guide lending and nonlending 
operations based on the analyses completed in this TA, interviews with the PRC 
officials, recent studies, policy changes, and other inputs. 
(x)  Organize, hold, and report on a closing national workshop for the TA in Beijing.  
In addition to central, provincial and municipal governments, participants will 
include representatives from the World Bank, European Union, Japan Bank for 
International Cooperation, and other bilateral agencies with urban operations in 
the PRC.  The purpose of this workshop will be to present and review all TA 
findings with a focus on the recommended policy framework and the PRC–ADB 
urban strategy.  
(xi)  Review all available ADB Operations Evaluation Department evaluation reports 
on performance of the integrated urban development projects (IUDPs), lessons 
learned,  conclusions  and  recommendations.  Assess  the  feasibility  of  all 
appropriate approaches (IUDP and others) for adoption in developing the PRC 
urban sector. 
(xii)  Identify  ADB's  relevance  and  value-added  for  governance  and  financing 
activities. The analyses of governance and finance are especially important to 
part C of the study, where the consultants will develop an "action plan to guide 
lending and nonlending operations". The action plan for ADB's involvement in 
supporting integrated urban development should be based on an understanding 
of what the urban areas can do on their own and where ADB's help is relevant 
and can add value. The consultants will review urban areas' access to domestic 
and international credit markets to identify the relevance and value-added of 
ADB's financing, and how ADB can help improve access. The consultants will 
also review planning and technical needs (in engineering, finance, environment, 
etc), to understand the kind of technical assistance that will be relevant for ADB 
to supply, and how ADB can help improve capacities. 
(xiii)  Review lessons learned in ADB's IUDP projects in other countries. ADB has 
made many loans for integrated urban development in the past, especially in 
South Asia.  Review all relevant project completion reports, project performance 
reports, and special evaluation studies that describe the problems with integrated 
urban development projects and the conclusions and recommendations. When 
the consultants develop the action plan (see (xii), above), they should review the 
lessons  learned  in  other  urban  development  projects.  They  should  also 
recommend a framework for choosing the type of loan.

14  Appendix 3 
 
(xiv)  During TA implementation, the ADB ECRD, Governance, Finance, and Trade 
Division will be consulted on the feasibility of financial intermediation loans in the 
PRC and the Government’s views on and willingness to undertake such loans.  
 
F.  Reporting 
11.  The consultants will submit an inception report within 1 month of commencing their 
consultancies, an interim report on completion of part C after 5 months, a draft final report 
(including the PRC–ADB urban strategy) after 7 months, and a final report after 8 months.  The 
results of the study will be disseminated in part through a series of workshops in Beijing and in 
working meetings in the case study provinces and municipalities. 
 
12.  The inception report will include a work plan, the identification of potential risks to TA 
implementation, and proposed mitigation measures, and a summary of key findings to date.   
 
13.  The  interim  report  will  document  parts  A,  B,  and  C  described  above.    A  10-page 
summary of the interim report will be prepared in Chinese. 
 
14.  The draft final report will document all findings and recommendations of the TA.  It will 
be accompanied by a summary report (maximum 20 pages).  Both will be translated into 
Chinese.  The final report will be completed after comments are received from NDRC and ADB.  
 
15.  The PRC–ADB urban strategy will be a stand-alone document and will be translated into 
Chinese.
